data.title: beautiful
data.text: it is right next to the Capitol and it is a very beautiful Church. We parked in the Garage and walked straight up to the Church.

data.title: Beautiful Church
data.text: We were told about the amazing stained glass windows by the capitol building guide and are very glad we visited. The tiffany glass windows are stunning and the church is clearly very well maintained and cared for.

data.title: Lovely church, beautiful stained glass windows
data.text:
Our guide in the State Capitol urged us to visit St Paul's church nearby.
We are glad that we did - it's a great example of open, welcoming church architecture, built some 150 years ago in the Greek Revival style.

There are a considerable number of splendid stained glass windows, four of which are Tiffany designed glass.

The whole atmosphere in the church is delightful - it's well worth a visit.
There is also a quiet garden alongside where one can sit and contemplate........

data.title: Beautiful church open to the public
data.text: This church is across from the state capitol. I went to see the amazing Tiffany stained glass windows, but was also impressed by the overall beauty of the entire sanctuary. Both Robert E. Lee and Jefferson Davis attended this church.

data.title: Gorgeous church!!
data.text: Beautiful church with the most amazing stained glass windows that I have ever seen.  The organ on the top level is also great to see.  The pews that Robert E. Lee and Jefferson Davis used are marked with plaques.  The whole church is very accessible and well worth the visit.

data.title: Historical Church in Downtown Richmond
data.text:
I found out a relative of mine was the lead soloist and choir director of St. Paul's Episcopal Church during the latter years of the Civil War, so during a recent visit to Richmond, I had to visit it.

The church is across the street from the State Capital complex in downtown Richmond. Parking is available apparently during the week in their garage or you can find public and private parking lots in the area. 

During the day, the church is open and available for viewing, though there is no organized tour or anyone to give information about the history of the congregation (at least not when we were there). The sanctuary is well preserved and the stained glass windows are well worth the trip. You can find the pews reserved for Jefferson Davis and Robert E. Lee and their families. 

Well worth a stop in Richmond.

data.title: Great Interests For Jefferson Davis and Robert E Lee Followers
data.text:
This is near the Confederacy White House and Confederacy Museum.  No Admission.  A very lovely historical church whose members included Jefferson Davis and Robert E Lee and their families while in Richmond Virginia.  Plaques on the side of the benches show where each family sat.  Like other commentators, it has a lovely organ and very beautiful stained glass windows.   

A lovely small garden is next to it. A very nice place to view and perhaps reflect on history, self or other matters.

data.title: Beautiful Church
data.text: This is a beautiful church with a lot of history. We took a quick walk through. It is Definitely worth a stop if you are near by.

data.title: Beautiful church
data.text: Loved this church. Beautiful pipe organ. The windows are art.  The ceiling is also very beautiful and inspiring.  There is a sweet little garden on the side with a fountain.

data.title: Pre-Civil War Episcopal Church
data.text: If you are visiting Richmond, don't miss a visit to St. Paul's.  This was Robert E. Lee's home church.  It has a fantastic organ and beautiful stained glass windows.

data.title: Beautful!
data.text: Wonderful stained glass all around and the Organ upstairs is amazing. It must be pretty to attend services here- working church.

data.title: Nice place for worship
data.text: But even if you don't want to go in for a prayer, it is worthwhile to visit this church with nice decorated windows. A visit offers also a moment of silence and cooling in the heat of the day.

data.title: Stained glass windows galore!
data.text: My sisters and I stopped by St Paul's church right after touring the Richmond Capitol. Wow! The stained glass windows are simple gorgeous! It was fun finding the places (pews) where famous people from history sat.

data.title: A Very Old and Beautiful House Of Worship
data.text: A historic structure right in the heart of the city only steps from the Virginia Capitol grounds, St. Paul's is a nice way to spend some time meditating on it's history and beautiful Tiffany stained glass windows. Worth the time, and could be done in conjunction with the Capitol tour.

data.title: Tiffany Window!
data.text: Need I say more?  This is a beautiful church located next to the capitol building.  The windows are magnificent.  Well worth the stop.

data.title: Ash Wednesday @ St. Pauls
data.text: Beautiful, stunning historical church in the middle of downtown Richmond. Very welcoming congregation. Relevant homily. Great, moving experience.

data.title: Architecture, History and Tiffany Windows!
data.text: This Church has seen a lot of history!  Jefferson Davis and Robert E Lee are only two of the numerous famous attendees.  Douglas Wilder, our first African-American Governor, had his pre-inaugural prayer service here.  While not all of the stained glass windows are Tiffany, many are - and they are beautiful!  I think 3 or 4 windows are from Monumental  Church, St John's parent church.  Outstanding Greek Revival architecture!  On the National Register of Historic Places and Virginia Landmarks Register.

data.title: Loved the viewed
data.text: The outside of the church is beautiful and sits cross form another church and the park.  It has some beautiful artwork and architectural elements.  A great spot to visit if you have a few spare minutes.

data.title: Beautiful stained glass Windows depicting religious events.
data.text: This is a church with beautiful stoned glass windows Nd historical significance. Take th guide at the vestibule so you can see where historical personalities sat.

data.title: St. Paul's Episcopal Church
data.text: Jefferson Davis was in attendance for a Sunday morning service when one of his aides came in to tell him he must evacuate Richmond.  The church is a terrific community resource; they allow people who live on the street inside to take showers.  They have hosted several programs in conjunction with Richmond's Journey.
